title: Ticket #589: Condor security manual updates
description:
In general, the security section of the manual should be improved, and some explicit examples/recipes should be provided (probably on the HOWTO section of the wiki, and the Manual could refer to them). Currently much of this explicit HOWTO wisdom only lives in Zach's powerpoint files.

Other thoughts -

ANONYMOUS causes the user to be identified as "CONDOR_ANONYMOUS_USER" This is completely insecure, but may be suitable for limited purposes. For example, ANONYMOUS access could be used to allow public read-only access to a collector or schedd.

A bunch of stuff that might be appropriate to add somewhere:

- FS - Very secure. Easy to set up. Only works for communications on a single computer. I recommend always using this.

- PASSWORD - Very secure. Moderate complexity to set up. Only works for authenticating daemon-to-daemon communications.

- SSL - Very secure. Complex to set up. Suitable for all purposes.

- GSI - Very secure. Very complex to set up. Suitable for all purposes. This is really just SSL with additional functionality to support the Globus Security Infrastructure. If you are not already using Globus for other purposes, I recommend against this. May not be available for Windows.

- KERBEROS - Very secure. Very complex to set up. Suitable for all purposes. If you are not already using Kerberos for other purposes, I recommend against this. May not be available for Windows.

- FS_REMOTE - Variable security. Moderate complexity to set up. Relies on the security of your network filesystem for security. I recommend NOT using.

- NTSSPI - Low security. Easy to set up. Microsoft Windows authentication. Only works on Windows. Authentication is security, but encryption and integrity checks are not.

- CLAIMTOBE - Insecure. Easy to set up. If enabled, anyone can claim to be anyone! It's really just for debugging. I recommend NOT using.

- ANONYMOUS - Insecure. Easy to set up. While insecure, it does limit users to the "CONDOR_ANONYMOUS_USER", a rough equivalent to unix's "nobody" account or Window's "guest". it can be useful if you want to allow read-only public access to parts of the system.

You can use more than one, and I recommend that you do so. My general recommendation is:

1. Use FS. It's simple and secure. In a typical configuration users run condor_submit on the same computer that the condor_schedd is running on. In this case, FS is easy for both administrators and users.

2. Users frequently ant read-only access to at least the condor_collector. This makes it easier for them to check the state of the pool, and is required to "condor_q -analyze" or "-better-analyze" to work. If your collector information is public, you can use ANONYMOUS to accomplish this easily. If this isn't public, use the same option described in #3 below.

3. If users want to be able to use "condor_submit -remote", "condor_q -name" or other remote access, you'll need another system beyond FS. If you are already using GSI for other purposes, I recommend GSI. If you are already using Kerberos for other purposes, I recommend KERBEROS. Otherwise SSL is the easiest secure option.

4. Condor daemons need to authenticate as well. If you're using SSL, GSI, or KERBEROS, you can probably also use it for the daemons. Otherwise I recommend PASSWORD as the easiest secure option.
remarks:
2012-Aug-17 10:04:20 by smoler:
From Todd T: In the security section of the manual, we list the available authentication methods, but we do not point out that not all methods are supported on all platforms. See the below post to condor-users. Todd

On 8/16/2012 9:01 PM, Jewell, Chris wrote: 

> Hi,
>
> I've just downloaded the Windows binaries for Condor 7.8.2, and am trying to configure GSI security.  I get messages such as:
>
> *** Last 20 line(s) of file C:\condor/log/NegotiatorLog:
> 08/17/12 13:42:24 SECMAN: new session, doing initial authentication.
> 08/17/12 13:42:24 SECMAN: Auth methods: GSI
> 08/17/12 13:42:24 HANDSHAKE: in handshake(my_methods = 'GSI')
> 08/17/12 13:42:24 HANDSHAKE: handshake() - i am the client
> 08/17/12 13:42:24 HANDSHAKE: sending (methods == 32) to server
> 08/17/12 13:42:24 HANDSHAKE: server replied (method = 32)
> 08/17/12 13:42:24 AUTHENTICATE: unsupported method: 32, failing.
>
> Does this mean that the Windows version is not GSI capable?
>

Correct.  GSI has never been ported to Windows. If you want something similar on Windows,
consider SSL, which also uses public key certificates (but doesn't do the limited proxy delegation that GSI does).

These Condor authentication methods work on Condor for Windows:

    SSL
    KERBEROS
    PASSWORD
    NTSSPI
    CLAIMTOBE
    ANONYMOUS

and these Condor authentication methods do not work on Windows:

    GSI
    FS
    FS_REMOTE

2013-Aug-26 15:09:23 by bbockelm:
Zach - for PASSWORD security, we should make a note that this is based on shared secret (right?) - one credential compromise on any node means all nodes could be compromised. That makes its use inappropriate in several uncommon use cases.
